text_image_relationship.layout_style: Single column of text with a full-width historiated initial at the top; the miniature occupies the space of the initial 'O' at the beginning of the psalm, with the main text resuming directly beneath; narrow margins largely left blank except for a small red rubric below the image.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata, executed in a professional book hand with regular, angular letterforms and red rubricated capitals; extensive use of standard medieval abbreviations and ligatures.

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf background reserved for the divine throne space; ultramarine and vermilion used alternately in the robes of attendant figures to signify rank; layered application of pigments with white lead highlights on drapery folds; red and blue border bands with white pattern serve to frame the scene and echo the rubric below.

features: Enthroned central figure on a dais
Symmetrical flanking groups of three figures on each side
Vertical axis through the king’s head and scepter
Overlap of figures to suggest shallow depth
Framed by a simple painted border

decorative_elements: Blue and red border bands with white wave and dot motifs
Red rubric line directly below miniature

drawing_technique.line_style: Fine, even black ink outlines drawn with a quill pen; bold contours define figures with thinner internal lines for facial details and drapery folds.
drawing_technique.shading_method: Minimal shading achieved through flat color fields; white lead highlights applied to raised gesso areas of gold and to accent drapery ridges; slight parallel hatching in ink to suggest fold depth.
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling with the enthroned figure slightly larger than attendants; no attempt at linear perspective; depth implied solely by overlapping figures.

content_theme.scene_description: A single historiated scene illustrating the initial 'O' of Psalm 95 (Omnes reges terrae). At center, a crowned king sits frontally on a low stone dais, wearing a rose-pink robe and red mantle, holding a gold scepter in his left hand and raising his right hand to his chest. He is surrounded by six bearded noblemen—three to his left and three to his right—each clad in red tunics and ultramarine cloaks, wearing pointed hats indicative of secular status. Two of the nearest attendants extend their hands in a gesture of offering or homage toward the king. Figures overlap slightly in a shallow picture plane, creating a sense of depth. The background is burnished gold leaf, symbolizing the divine realm. Below the scene, a narrow red rubric band marks the continuation of the psalm text. The border comprises alternating blue and red bands decorated with white wave and dot motifs, echoing the color hierarchy of the miniature. Symbolic elements include the crown, scepter, and gold ground, reinforcing themes of divine authority and the homage of earthly rulers.

secular: Crowned king in rose-pink robe and red mantle with gold crown and scepter
Six noble attendants in red tunics, ultramarine cloaks, and pointed secular hats

technical_features.material: Premium calf vellum, vellum folio with uniform thickness and smooth, well-pumiced surface; the hair-side shows subtle follicle patterns visible under raking light.
technical_features.preservation_condition: Overall excellent preservation; vivid pigments with minimal darkening of the gold leaf; slight flaking of vermilion at drapery edges; no evidence of major conservation intervention except minor contemporary margin reinforcement.
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso preparation beneath gold leaf creating a slight relief
Underdrawing traced in brown ink visible under UV illumination
Regular ruling pattern from plummet visible around the miniature
Layered pigment application with visible brush strokes in drapery folds

functional_analysis.intended_audience: Individual patron, likely a member of the nobility using the psalter for personal prayer

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This historiated initial belongs to a mid-13th-century French psalter, likely produced in a Parisian workshop under Angevin influence. The presentation of Psalm 95 with Christ or a typological king enthroned among secular rulers reflects the contemporaneous theological emphasis on Christ as cosmic monarch, invoked in liturgical recitation. The refined Gothic textura script and lavish application of ultramarine and gold leaf suggest an affluent patron—possibly a noble or royal client—seeking a personal devotional volume that also proclaimed status. Stylistically, the image demonstrates the transition from more rigid Romanesque forms toward the graceful, elongated figures characteristic of the high Gothic, with subtle naturalism in the modelling of drapery and faces. The symmetrical composition and restrained spatial overlap are typical of mid-13th-century iconographic conventions, while the use of raised gesso and layered pigments indicates advanced technical practice in illumination. Iconographically, the crown and scepter underscore the universal sovereignty of Christ, an idea reinforced by the accompanying rubric ‘Omnes reges terrae adoremus te.’ Comparatively, this miniature shares compositional affinities with the Psalter of Blanche of Castile (BnF Latin 115) but reveals a more subdued color palette and simpler border ornamentation, suggesting either a different workshop tier or a later regional adaptation. The image thus epitomizes the synthesis of devotional function, political messaging, and artistic innovation in Gothic illumination.
